awd_titl_txt: EAPSI: Comparing pre-service Teacher Motivation in Teacher Preparation Programs in Singapore and the United States to Improve Learning Outcomes
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to create online teacher preparation courses that include the 
program attributes and curricula that have made the teacher preparation program at the National Institute of Education in Singapore an internationally ranked program. In collaboration with Dr. Zachary Walker, professor of Early Childhood and Special Education and expert in mobile learning, existing traditional courses will be adapted into courseware that can be completed online instead of a traditional classroom. Online courseware will include rigorous content and development of a learning community in the online environment. The researchers will identify the instructional strategies, curriculum design, and student-to- professor, student, content relationships that will increase and sustain student motivation to learn. The researchers seek to increase availability of a high-quality curriculum for teacher preparation without the constraints of the traditional higher education program. 

The goal of this project is to create online teacher preparation courses that include the 
program attributes and curricula that have made the teacher preparation program at the National Institute of Education in Singapore, ranked 10th in the world. In collaboration with Dr. Zachary Walker, professor of Early Childhood and Special Education and expert in mobile learning, the researchers will identify curriculum elements including instructional strategy, practice method, and motivational factors. These elements will be used to design rigorous, asynchronous courseware combined with strategies to develop virtual learning communities.  Researchers will measure elements of student motivation; specifically, self-regulation, self-efficacy, and goal orientation. Researchers will also measure readiness for online learning, connectedness, and learning outcomes at each institution following administration of the asynchronous courseware developed during the research program. The research outcomes will increase the rigor, quality, and availability of teacher preparation courseware.

This award under the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes program supports summer research by a U.S. graduate student and is jointly funded by NSF and the National Research Foundation of Singapore.

por.por_cntn:
The traditional higher education paradigm consisting of a professor-led, seat-based learning environment can restrict learning opportunities for both traditional and nontraditional students (i.e. employed full-time, single parents, restrictive physical condition). Asynchronous, online learning environments can eliminate time and distance restrictions; however, they may pose a new set of learning obstacles related to the quality of the instructional materials, the feeling of connectedness, and the necessary self-regulation skills. Existing research shows that these factors impact completion rates and learners’ overall satisfaction with the online course as a viable learning environment (Cho & Shen, 2013). This research project consisted of the redevelopment of an online course Characteristics of Students with Mild to Moderate Intervention Needs for teachers of students with special needs. The Quality Matters Course Development Rubric and the inclusion of curriculum and practices from the National Institute of Education (NIE) in Singapore to guide courseware redevelopment. NIE is currently ranked 10th in the world in Education according to the QS World University Rankings. The research project examined the teaching methods and curriculum at NIE and combined scaffolded self-regulation strategies for learning in an online environment. Researchers will continue to use developed courseware and the Online Learning Readiness Questionnaire and the Motivated Strategies for Learning Questionnaire to  examine motivation, course satisfaction, as well as overall content learning with groups of students at NIE and at Kent State University.

The primary goal of this project was to learn about the structure of the teacher education program at the National Institute of Education in Singapore. The Principal Investigator, aided by the host researcher, met this goal by beginning a comparative analysis of the teacher education program at NIE and the teacher education program at Kent State University which is fairly representative of teacher education programs in the United States. The PI will use this data to continue analysis of teacher education programs across the US.

The second goal that was met was to develop courseware for both the host researcher and the Principal Investigator. The learning activities that were developed will continue to be used to examine the relation between learning outcomes, motivation orientation and readiness for online learning in students in both programs. The PI and host researcher will continue to collect data in order to answer two primary research questions. These questions will help identify differences between the teacher education programs and the motivation of students who embark on the journey to become teachers. Specific research questions below were designed to increase the number of rigorous, high-quality online courses and to increase the student success rate and overall course satisfaction.


1) Will intentional activities to develop social connectedness combined with instruction on and support of self-regulated learning lead to increased student success and overall course satisfaction in a rigorous online course?

2) What role, if any, do culture and educational belief systems play in student success in a rigorous online learning environment?


As the traditional paradigm in higher education shifts towards a more asynchronous, student-centered instructional design, it is essential to develop high-quality online content using evidence-based practices. The instructional design of the content and scaffolded self-regulation activities, can lead to an increase in successful course completion. The benefits of online learning and high-quality curriculum have been well-documented. Often, excellent curriculum is provided but the design fails to include effective strategies for learners to self-regulate which is critical for success in an online learning environment (Zimmerman,1990). This collaboration combines both the exceptional curriculum from the NIE, self-regulation strategies described in the literature, and social connectedness components which will be put into practice and compared across learner groups.

The knowledge gained in this project will lead to increased development of and high-quality online courses in higher education. This will provide more opportunities for the nontraditional and underrepresented student to obtain a college degree without the constraints of the typical college campus and schedule. Courses that include engaging content combined with self-regulated learning strategies don’t require students to learn in a building on a fixed schedule. Instead, students with disabilities, students who are not near a college campus, or those who are prevented from attending a campus-based program due to their race or gender, will be offered the opportunity to gain the skills and knowledge needed in local and global communities.
